Scott:

Have you identified how a test-driven class implements a FSM? If I give
you some code that I test-drove, would you try identifying how it is a
FSM? That would be very interesting.

Thanks.

So said  Eric Armstrong  on  2003-02-04 --------------------

>This is really profound. I've implemented fsm's before, but never
>characterized a "testable app" as one that effectively *is* one.
>
>I've summarized the key points of your post below. It's going to
>bear more rumination...
>
>Scott Stirling wrote:
>
>>  I've been thinking about Test Driven Development and the question
of
>> what is it about it that ensures testability.
>> ....
>> Obviously, a method added for no other purpose than to make a
class's
>> behavior more directly accessible to external tests ... enhances the
>> testability of a class.
>> ....
>> So how do you make things testable without corrupting the object
>> design with behaviors added or modified just to make objects
>> testable?  And why is it that test driven development, practiced
>> religiously, will typically give you 100% statement coverage without
>> adding any test-only methods to a class?
>>
>> I think the answer has to do with finite-state machines.  TDD is a
>> methodology that results in the development of clean, working
>> finite-state machines.  It works so well because the methodology of
>> writing tests first drives the mental process to identify and make
>> explicit, in the appropriate order of priority:
>> 1. the desired outputs
>> 2. the inputs and behaviors needed to transition the machine from an
>> initial or existing state to desired output
>> 3. the objects that compose the machine (one of the least important
>> things at first, contrary to more traditional design
>> methodology)....the naming of the objects and definition of their
>> boundaries evolves as the 1st and 2nd priorities are realized.
>>
>> It seems the best way to build and test a finite-state machine is to
>> make the inputs and outputs explicit, and to make the state
>> transitions step-wise and traceable.  It's a fallout from object
>> oriented programming constraints that the steps become methods in
>> objects, and the traceability of the steps becomes actualized in
your
>> unit test methods and TestCases.
>>
>> After doing TDD, traceability and explicit inputs and outputs are
what
>> you've built into your application and which remain, even if you
take
>> away the unit tests when you're done.
>>
>> So going back to the question of testability, I think there are some
>> basic things that automatically result in testability in OOP (this
>> list by no means accurate or exhaustive, and inspired by some
reading
>> about state machines in the testing literature, namely Beizer and
>> Binder):
>>   - objects or collaborations of objects modeled as finite-state
>> machines
>>   - methods for making state transitions in the objects themselves
or
>> in other objects
>>   - explicit inputs to and outputs from methods
>>   - step-wise, traceable state transitions
>
>Note:
>Here, I find that I need an example to follow the discussion.
>
>> I think these things become realized in terms of language and design
>> specifics.  For example:
>>   - traceability requires state transition methods to be accessible
>> for unit testing
>>   - state must be verifiable via attributes or methods that return
>> state information and can be used in assertions
>>   - step-wise means you don't make monolithic, god methods or
classes
>> that hide multiple, untraceable transitions
>>   - explicit inputs means that something like the method below
should
>> be tuned based on the fact that the Connection object is the
*actual*
>> input needed for the behavior to do its thing:

>Where you working? (I was at D.G.)
>
